description.narrative:
Additional detail on PEPFAR financial information and terminology can be found at https://data.pepfar.gov/financial. The PEPFAR IATI activity file and PEPFAR IATI Activity File User's Guide can be found at https://data.pepfar.gov/additionalData
The program goal (2010-2016) is to increase healthy behaviors to reduce HIV/AIDS transmission among KP and other vulnerable populations through increased condom use, reduced number of sexual partners, and increased access to HIV testing. Program success will be measured by: 1) Increase in 50% the consistent use of condoms; 2) decrease of 30% the number of multiple partners; and 3) increase of 60% in the use of HIV counseling and testing. By working through local NGOs to provide the HIV prevention services, this program enables the NGOs to continue and expand their combination prevention efforts focused on KP. It also builds their institutional capacity and provides them with the tools needed to increase impact, and to further develop strategies for sustainability. The program has four overall expected results: a) Strengthened Institutional Capacity; b) Improved Access to and Quality of HIV/AIDS Prevention Services; c) Reduction of Stigma and Discrimination Directed Against KP and PLHIV and d) Improved Participation of NGOs Representing KP and PLHIV in the National Response to HIV/AIDS. Forty local NGOs reach 35,000 KPs annually in every department of Nicaragua. The strategy is to become more cost efficient over time. At the end of the project local NGOs will be able to provide combination prevention services and mobilize funds from other donors. For M&E, the plans are to implement a unique registry system this year to monitor all individuals reached and an evaluation of the training component and secondary analysis of VCT services. A final evaluation is planned for FY 2016.objectives

policy-marker.narrative: The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) is the U.S. government's response to the global HIV/AIDS epidemic and represents the largest commitment by any nation to address a single disease in history.
